title: Lesson 23: Comparing the Properties of Mixtures and Compounds
content:
Lesson 23: Comparing the Properties of Mixtures and Compounds

The Ultimate Chemistry Showdown

You take some yellow powder and some grey metal filings. If you just stir them, you get a simple mix. But if you heat them until they glow, you get a new black solid. Both started with the same ingredients, so what's the big difference? Let's explore the epic battle between a simple get-together (a mixture) and a permanent transformation (a compound)!

Mixture vs. Compound: A Head-to-Head Battle

Let's put mixtures and compounds in the ring together and compare them point-for-point. This table will make the differences crystal clear.

Property Mixtures Compounds
1. Formation

Elements or compounds just physically mix together. No new substance is formed.

Elements chemically react to form a brand new substance.
2. Composition

The composition is variable. You can mix the components in any ratio you want.

The composition is always fixed. The "recipe" for a compound never changes.
3. Properties

A mixture shows the properties of its individual components.

e.g., A mix of iron and sulphur is still grey (from iron) and yellow (from sulphur).

The new substance has totally different properties from its original elements.

e.g., Iron sulphide (a compound) is a black solid, not grey or yellow.
4. Separation

Components can be separated fairly easily by physical methods (like magnets, filtering, etc.).

Components can only be separated by chemical or electrochemical reactions.

Let's See it in Action!

Remember our iron and sulphur experiment? It perfectly illustrates the difference between a mixture and a compound.

Group I: The Mixture

You simply stir iron filings and sulphur powder together.

  • It's a mixture. No chemical reaction occurred.
  • It keeps the properties of its parts. For example, the iron is still magnetic.
  • It can be separated physically. A magnet will pull the iron out, leaving the sulphur behind.

Group II: The Compound

You heat the mixture strongly until it glows red hot.

  • It's a compound (Iron Sulphide). A chemical reaction took place.
  • It has new properties. The new substance is black and non-magnetic.
  • It cannot be separated physically. A magnet has no effect because the iron is chemically bonded to the sulphur.

Key Takeaways: The Final Verdict

Mixture

  • How it's made:Just mixed
  • Ratio:Variable
  • Properties:Keeps originals
  • Separation:Physical methods
  • Example:Salad, salt water

Compound

  • How it's made:Chemical reaction
  • Ratio:Fixed
  • Properties:Completely new
  • Separation:Chemical reactions
  • Example:Water, table salt
questions:
Lesson 23: Questions on Comparing Mixtures and Compounds

1. You stir salt into a glass of water to make salt water. Separately, you know that table salt itself (Sodium Chloride, NaCl) is made from the elements sodium and chlorine. Which one is the mixture and which one is the compound? Explain your reasoning.

Salt Water

Table Salt

Step 1: Analyze the salt water. - Can you change the amount of salt? Yes (variable ratio). - Does it taste salty? Yes (keeps original properties). - Can you get the salt back by boiling the water? Yes (physical separation). - Conclusion: These are properties of a mixture.

Step 2: Analyze the table salt (NaCl). - Is the ratio of Na to Cl always 1:1? Yes (fixed ratio). - Is salt anything like sodium (explosive metal) or chlorine (poisonous gas)? No (new properties). - Can you get the sodium back by boiling the salt? No (needs chemical separation). - Conclusion: These are properties of a compound.

Answer:

  • Salt water is a mixture. The salt and water are just physically mixed, they keep their own properties, and they can be separated by physical means like evaporation.
  • Table salt (NaCl) is a compound. The sodium and chlorine are chemically bonded in a fixed ratio, creating a new substance with totally different properties.

2. A student stirs iron filings and sulphur powder together (Group I). Another student heats the same mixture until it glows and forms a black solid (Group II). Which group created a compound, and how could they prove it using a magnet?

Step 1: Analyze Group I. Stirring is a physical process. The iron and sulphur are just mixed. This is a mixture.

Step 2: Analyze Group II. Heating until it glows indicates a chemical reaction. A new substance is formed. This is a compound.

Step 3: Consider the magnet test. Iron is magnetic. A magnet can physically separate components. In a compound, the iron loses its original properties.

Answer:

  • Group II created the compound (iron sulphide) because heating caused a chemical reaction.
  • How to prove it:
    • If Group I brings a magnet to their mixture, the magnet will pull out the iron filings, proving it's a mixture where iron kept its magnetic property.
    • If Group II brings a magnet to their new black solid, nothing will happen. This proves a new, non-magnetic substance was formed, which is a key characteristic of a compound.

3. Is lemonade a mixture or a compound? Justify your answer with two key differences from the comparison table.

Answer: Lemonade is a mixture.

Justification:

  1. Variable Composition: You can make lemonade more or less sweet/sour by changing the amount of sugar or lemon juice. The ratio of components is not fixed. In a compound, the ratio is always fixed.
  2. Properties of Components are Retained: The lemonade tastes sweet because of the sugar and sour because of the lemon. The components keep their original properties. In a compound, entirely new properties are formed.

4. List three ways in which compounds are different from mixtures.

Answer: Three key differences are:

Feature Compounds Mixtures
1. PropertiesHave new, different properties.Retain properties of components.
2. CompositionHave a fixed ratio of components.Have a variable ratio.
3. SeparationSeparated by chemical reactions.Separated by physical methods.

5. Look at the two diagrams below. Which one represents a mixture of elements and which one represents a compound? Explain.

Diagram X
Diagram Y

Answer:

  • Diagram X represents a mixture.
    Explanation: It shows two different types of particles (blue and red), but they are all separate and not bonded to each other. They are just physically mixed in the same container.
  • Diagram Y represents a compound.
    Explanation: It shows that the blue and red particles have chemically bonded together to form new, identical units. Every particle in the box is the same combined unit.

6. Air is made of about 78% nitrogen gas, 21% oxygen gas, and small amounts of other gases. Is air a mixture or a compound?

Step 1: Check the composition. The text says the amounts are "about 78%" and "21%". This implies the ratio is variable, not fixed.

Step 2: Check the properties. The oxygen in the air is still used for breathing, and the other gases retain their properties. The components have not changed into a new substance.

Answer: Air is a mixture.

Explanation: Its components (nitrogen, oxygen, etc.) are not chemically bonded, they retain their individual properties, and their composition can vary slightly from place to place. These are all characteristics of a mixture.

7. When a new compound is formed, is energy (like heat or light) usually involved? Is energy usually involved when you make a mixture?

Answer:

  • Compounds: Yes. The formation of a compound involves a chemical reaction, which usually either releases energy (like the glowing of iron and sulphur) or absorbs energy.
  • Mixtures: No. Making a mixture is a physical change, and it usually does not involve any significant energy change. Simply stirring salt in water doesn't produce heat or light.

8. You are given two unlabeled beakers. Beaker A contains a liquid that can be separated into two different liquids by boiling it at a specific temperature (distillation). Beaker B contains a liquid that can only be separated into hydrogen and oxygen gas by passing electricity through it. Identify which beaker contains a mixture and which contains a compound.

Step 1: Analyze the separation method for Beaker A. Distillation is a physical separation method based on different boiling points. If something can be separated physically, it's a mixture.

Step 2: Analyze the separation method for Beaker B. Passing electricity to break something down (electrolysis) is a chemical separation method. If something needs a chemical method to be separated, it's a compound.

Answer:

  • Beaker A contains a mixture (e.g., alcohol and water).
  • Beaker B contains a compound (e.g., pure water, H₂O).

10. What's wrong with this statement? "Water is a mixture of hydrogen and oxygen because it contains both elements."

Answer: The statement is wrong because it ignores how the elements are combined.

Explanation: Although water contains hydrogen and oxygen, they are not just physically mixed. They are chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio to form a new substance. This chemical bonding is what makes it a compound, not a mixture.
exercises:
Lesson 23: Exercises on Comparing Mixtures and Compounds

1. Classify It! Categorize each of the following substances as either a Mixture or a Compound.

  • Air (Nitrogen, Oxygen, etc.): ______________
  • Pure Water (H₂O): ______________
  • Soil (Sand, Clay, Organic matter): ______________
  • Table Sugar (Sucrose, C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁): ______________
  • Salt Water: ______________
  • Baking Soda (Sodium Bicarbonate, NaHCO₃): ______________

Answers:

  • Air: Mixture
  • Pure Water (H₂O): Compound
  • Soil: Mixture
  • Table Sugar (Sucrose, C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁): Compound
  • Salt Water: Mixture
  • Baking Soda (Sodium Bicarbonate, NaHCO₃): Compound

2. Analogy Check: A student makes two analogies. Which one is better? Explain why.

Analogy A: "A mixture is like a playlist of songs, and a compound is like a completely new remixed song."
Analogy B: "A mixture is like a finished LEGO car model, and a compound is like a loose pile of LEGO bricks."

Answer: Analogy A is better.

Explanation:

  • Analogy A works well: In a playlist (mixture), the original songs (components) are still identifiable and can be easily separated. In a remix (compound), the original pieces are chemically changed into a new song with new properties that can't be easily taken apart.
  • Analogy B is incorrect: It has the concepts reversed. The loose pile of bricks is the mixture (easily separated, no fixed structure), and the finished LEGO model is the compound (fixed structure, new properties).

3. Choose the Right Method: For each scenario, choose whether a PHYSICAL or CHEMICAL method is needed for separation.

  • Getting sugar from a sugar-water solution: ______________
  • Getting hydrogen gas from a water molecule: ______________
  • Getting iron filings from a mix of iron and sand: ______________
  • Getting carbon from a sugar molecule (C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁): ______________

Answer:

  • Getting sugar from a sugar-water solution (a mixture): PHYSICAL (e.g., evaporation)
  • Getting hydrogen gas from a water molecule (a compound): CHEMICAL (e.g., electrolysis)
  • Getting iron filings from a mix of iron and sand (a mixture): PHYSICAL (e.g., using a magnet)
  • Getting carbon from a sugar molecule (a compound): CHEMICAL (e.g., burning)

4. Odd One Out: Which of the following does not belong with the others? Explain why.

Soil, Water (H₂O), Air, a bowl of mixed nuts

Answer: Water (H₂O) is the odd one out.

Explanation: Soil, air, and a bowl of mixed nuts are all mixtures. Their components are just physically combined and can be separated. Water is the only compound in the list, with its elements chemically bonded in a fixed ratio.

5. Property Check: Read the description and decide if it applies to a Mixture or a Compound.

"This substance was created without a chemical reaction. Its composition can be changed easily, and it still tastes sweet and sour, just like the sugar and lemon that were put into it."

Answer: This describes a Mixture.

Explanation: The key clues are: no chemical reaction, variable composition, and the components retaining their original properties (taste). These are all hallmarks of a mixture, like lemonade.

6. Visual Story: Look at the steps. At what point does the mixture become a compound?

Step 1: Get Ingredients

Step 2: Stir Together

Step 3: Heat Strongly

Answer: The mixture becomes a compound in Step 3.

Explanation: Step 2 creates a mixture. The addition of strong heat in Step 3 provides the energy for a chemical reaction, which is necessary to form the chemical bonds of a compound.

7. True or False: "You can make a compound by mixing two elements in any proportion you like." Explain your answer.

Answer: False.

Explanation: This describes a mixture. Compounds always have a fixed composition by mass. For example, water is always 2 parts hydrogen to 1 part oxygen (by atoms), and you cannot change this recipe.

8. What is the key difference between how a mixture is formed and how a compound is formed?

Answer:

The key difference is that a compound is formed through a chemical reaction where new chemical bonds are made, while a mixture is formed by simple physical mixing with no chemical bonds formed between the components.

9. A substance is made of two elements. The final product has properties totally different from the original elements. Is it a mixture or a compound?

Answer: It is a compound.

Explanation: The fact that the substance has completely new properties is the definitive sign of a compound. Mixtures always retain the properties of their components.

10. You make a salad dressing by shaking oil and vinegar together. If you let it sit, the oil and vinegar separate. Is this a mixture or a compound? Why?

Answer: It is a mixture.

Explanation: It's a mixture because the components can be easily separated by a physical method (letting them settle out). In a compound, the components are chemically bonded and cannot be separated so easily.

11. Which of these two statements is correct?

  • Statement A: A mixture of hydrogen and oxygen gas will behave just like hydrogen and oxygen.
  • Statement B: A compound of hydrogen and oxygen (water) will behave just like hydrogen and oxygen.

Answer: Statement A is correct.

Explanation: In a mixture, the components retain their properties. In a compound (like water), the substance has entirely new properties, different from its original elements.

12. Create a simple table with two columns, "Mixture" and "Compound," and place the following terms under the correct heading:
Fixed Ratio, Physical Separation, New Substance, Variable Ratio, Chemical Reaction

MixtureCompound
Variable RatioFixed Ratio
Physical SeparationNew Substance
Chemical Reaction

13. Does a compound have a fixed melting and boiling point? Does a mixture?

Answer:

  • Compounds: Yes. Because they are pure substances with a fixed composition, they have sharp, fixed melting and boiling points (e.g., pure water always boils at 100°C at sea level).
  • Mixtures: No. They typically melt or boil over a range of temperatures because their composition is variable.

14. Is it possible to have a mixture of compounds? Give an example.

Answer: Yes, it is very common.

Example: Salt water. Salt (Sodium Chloride) is a compound, and water (H₂O) is a compound. When you mix them, you get a mixture of two different compounds.

15. Draw It! In the boxes below, draw a simple particle diagram for:

A. A mixture of element X and element Y.

B. A compound made from element X and element Y.

A. A mixture of element X and element Y.

intros:
Lesson 23: Comparing the Properties of Mixtures and Compounds

Both mixtures and compounds involve putting substances together, but the way they combine changes everything! Let's put them side-by-side and see who's who in the ultimate chemistry face-off.

Intro 1: The Salad vs. The Cake

What's the real difference between tossing a salad and baking a cake?

Think about making food. A mixture is like a salad. You toss lettuce, tomatoes, and cucumbers together. They are all in the same bowl, but a tomato is still a tomato and lettuce is still lettuce. They keep their own properties, and you can easily pick them out if you don't like cucumbers!

A compound is like baking a cake. You take flour, sugar, eggs, and butter and mix them. But then, you add heat—a chemical reaction! The result is a cake, a completely new substance. It doesn't taste like raw eggs or flour anymore; it has its own new, delicious taste. You can't just pick the eggs back out of the finished cake. The ingredients have been transformed.

A mixture is just a get-together; a compound is a permanent transformation.

Intro 2: The Crowd vs. The Family

Are the people in a room just a random crowd, or are they a family with strong, unbreakable bonds?

A mixture is like a crowd of people at a bus stop. There are different individuals, but they aren't connected. Each person keeps their own identity, and anyone can leave at any time. You can have a big crowd or a small crowd; the ratio of people isn't fixed.

A compound is like a family. The members are held together by strong, permanent bonds. They act as a single unit with its own identity, different from the individuals that form it. A specific family (like the water family, H₂O) always has the same members in a fixed arrangement (two H members, one O member). You can't just easily pull them apart.

Mixtures are casual acquaintances; compounds are a tightly-knit family.

Intro 3: The Playlist vs. The Remix

What's the difference between a playlist of your favorite songs and a professional DJ remix?

A mixture is like a music playlist. You put several different songs together. Each song keeps its original sound and artist. You can easily add more songs, remove songs, or change the order. The components are just together in the same list.

A compound is like a professional DJ remix. The DJ takes elements from different songs—a beat from one, a vocal from another—and chemically combines them to create a brand new track. This new song has its own unique feel and rhythm. You can no longer hear the original songs in their entirety, and you certainly can't just 'remove' the beat from the new track. A transformation has occurred.

Mixtures are like a playlist of originals; compounds are a brand new remix.

Intro 4: The Lab Experiment

What's the difference between mixing two powders and heating them until they glow?

Let's do a thought experiment. If you take iron filings (grey, magnetic) and sulphur powder (yellow, non-magnetic) and just stir them together, you get a mixture. The iron is still iron, and the sulphur is still sulphur. You can prove this by using a magnet to pull the iron filings right out of the mixture. You separated them with a simple physical tool.

Now, what if you take that same mixture and heat it strongly? A chemical reaction occurs! The mixture glows, and when it cools, you have a new black, solid substance called iron sulphide. This is a compound. If you bring a magnet near it, nothing happens! The iron has lost its magnetic property. A new substance with new properties has been formed, and you can't separate it with a magnet anymore.

Just mixing keeps things the same; a chemical reaction changes everything.

Intro 5: The Superhero Team-Up

Are the two heroes just roommates, or have they fused into one?

Imagine two superheroes, Captain Red and Captain Blue, decide to team up. If they are a mixture, they are just roommates. They live in the same house, but Captain Red still has his red costume and powers, and Captain Blue has his. They work together but remain separate individuals.

But if they form a compound, it's like a magical fusion! Captain Red and Captain Blue merge to become a single, new hero: the amazing Captain Purple! This new hero doesn't have red powers or blue powers; they have brand new purple powers. They have a new identity, and you can't just ask them to split back into Red and Blue. The original heroes have been chemically changed into something else.

A mixture is a temporary alliance; a compound is a permanent fusion.
summary:
Lesson 23 Summary: Mixtures vs. Compounds

The ultimate head-to-head comparison.

Table 2.2: Mixtures vs. Compounds

Property Mixtures Compounds
Formation Elements or compounds just mix together. No new compound is formed. Elements react to form new compounds. A chemical change occurs.
Composition Has a variable composition. The ratio of components can change. The composition is always fixed by mass.
Properties Shows the properties of its constituent substances. The new substance has totally different properties from its elements.
Separation Constituents can be separated fairly easily by physical methods. Constituents can be separated only by chemical or electrochemical reactions.
Energy Change No energy (heat, light) is usually given out or absorbed. Energy is usually given out or absorbed during its formation.
